subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] keyboard/lexical set proposal
msgSnippet: ... My dictionary does not merge the lexical sets LOT THOUGHT and PALM, so it is more useful than the CMU dictionary. It is based on North American
messageBody:
Ted Larson Freeman wrote:
>
>
> Hi Paul,
>
> What is the scope of the dictionary you plan to create? If you want to
> include accents from the UK, for instance, I expect you'll need
> sources other than the CMU Dictionary. If you've found suitable
> sources for non-North American accents, please let us know
>
> Such a dictionary would be a valuable resource for the accents it
> represents accurately. It could drive applications that alter QS
> output on the fly based on a user's choice of accent, for example.
> That would be cool.

My dictionary does not merge the lexical sets LOT THOUGHT and PALM, so
it is more useful than the CMU dictionary. It is based on North American
pronunciation, however. That means the BATH and TRAP lexical sets are
merged. In order to find out what words in the current dictionary really
belong to BATH, we would have to check each dictionary with a British
dictionary. I think that would get us a nearly universal dictionary.

I'm not sure about CLOTH and LOT, though. Perhaps I also need to
separate out the LOT words into LOT and CLOTH.

>
> Now, the internal representation that you choose to use in the
> dictionary doesn't really matter. In the end you're going to display
> QS, so any notation will do. The QS-SAMPA proposal has a different
> purpose. It aims to provide a single standard for two things: (1) a
> keyboard layout that font developers can follow, and (2) a plain-text
> format that allows the easy exchange of QS text in email and other
> software applications.
>
> For these purposes, we need a one-to-one correspondence between the
> letters of the Read Alphabet and the ASCII notation we use to
> represent them. Otherwise, something typed in plain text will be
> ambiguous without another layer of information.
>
> I'm happy to debate the relative merits of the different proposals for
> an ASCII notation for the Read Alphabet. So far, I think we can count
> at least four or five. Unsurprisingly, I still like QS-SAMPA best.
>

I don't think we are going to reach any conclusion with more debate. We
may have to tolerate several ASCII encodings and proscribe Unicode when
we want to be consistent.

There are so many proposals at this point that I find it easier to think
in terms of lexical sets, because they break down the word into
phonemes. For example, my dictionary has _cure_ as [kjU@r]. Rather than
my having to think in terms of letters, it is easier for me to think
Kick-Yes-CURE, where the names in lower case represent psuedo lexical
sets, and the ones in caps represent real lexical sets. I like breaking
down a word into all of its phonemes because I am doing a lot of
dictionary editing right now.

Paul
